Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Quantification of Geography and Social Relations in Agrarian Reforms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award investigates how land and other resources are quantified in rural land reform projects. Land reforms reallocate access to primary productive resources. This reallocation critically depends on measurements and calculations that can vary significantly from one context to another. The researcher seeks to understand how these numbers are produced and how they are incorporated into governmental planning and design. The research is important because quantifications of all kinds, from national censuses to educational testing, have become a common part of contemporary life. This research focuses on the micro-processes by which the actual numbers are produced and who produces them. This information will help both policy makers who use numbers to make important decisions and citizens whose lives are affected by those decisions to better understand the complexities that can lie behind quantifications.

The research will be undertaken by Sheng Long, a University of Michigan anthropology doctoral student, who is supervised by Dr. Erik Mueggler. Long will use rural land reform in China as a case study. This major national quantification project provides a rich and unique opportunity that would not be available in the United States, although the results of her study will be applicable to the U.S. Long will investigate how rural residents and other social actors measure and calculate agricultural resources. She has structured her research with two sets of queries. The first set is about numerical governance. How do social actors--farmers, bureaucrats, government staff, and surveyors--produce numbers, individually and cooperatively, in land reforms? The second set of questions is about the quantification of personhood and belongings. How do people manipulate numerical standards that generate social labeling? How do they calculate land contextually when they shift social roles from household to neighborhood to community? Long will collect data in three major sites: village households and agricultural fields; a GIS survey company; and familial and institutional archives. Findings from the research will contribute to interdisciplinary theorization of social category and relations through the lens of numbers. It also will provide data for policymakers worldwide who need to understand how local population are drawn into, affect, and are affected by large-scale quantification projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

The NSF award was used for the Co-PI to conduct long-term fieldwork and archival research for the doctoral project. The dissertation project aims to provide an ethnographic study of how people use numbers to strategize in both agrarian reforms and agricultural production. The fieldwork was focused on two major parts: the nation-wide land census and the pomelo trees planting. The research was centered on rural residents? numerical practices, including the measurement and calculation of natural resources and social relations, which have long been overlooked in mainstream media and public discourses. 

The fieldwork has generated a considerable quantity of fieldwork data in textual, visual, and audio forms. Drawing from both the fieldwork data and archival research, the Co-PI is now writing up the dissertation, aiming to be one of the first monographs about the most recent land census in China. In the dissertation, the Co-PI asks an overarching question: how people understand the geography and themselves by numbers. The dissertation is arguing that the national land census, instead of being the most up-to-date and high-tech, is more of negotiation among multiple social groups--rural residents, cadres, and GIS surveyors. The census is part of an ongoing socio-economic reform, which is created out of historical memories and social relations. The project attempts to illustrate that rural residents, despite their silent roles in written histories, have played a significant role in land reforms across time. The dissertation will then move from the angle of the national land census to everyday agricultural production. The collected fieldwork data shows that people use multiple theories of numbers--be it cultural, historical, or spiritual--to calculate different geographies and properties. People also use their body to sense the time, space, and weight, to the extent that numbers become embodied as villagers ceaselessly engage in agricultural work that is laden with human labor. It is in the national projects such as land census and reforms when rural residents' numerical understanding of their paddy fields and fruit orchards turn into official numbers that will have an impact on future generations. 

The Co-PI plans to finish the dissertation write-up in 2021. Before the defense, at least one submission to journals is expected. The Co-PI has been trying to make the research communicable to a broader audience. She had frequent communication with scholars and students in the local university. She showed around the village to several scholars who were interested in researching similar topics. She also helped make connections for graduate students who might conduct fieldwork in the same region. During the fieldwork, the Co-PI had continuous conversations with a local resident about sorting out and analyzing his familial archives, more than 350 land deeds ranging from the mid-eighteen century to the mid-twentieth century. Recently, the archive keeper scanned and published all these land deeds for future scholarly research.
